newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Kuwait will not boost deal with Chevron.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait will not boost deal with Chevron.

text.p: Kuwait, which controls about 10 percent of the world's oil reserves, said on Saturday it does not plan to expand a deal with U.S.-based Chevron Corp beyond an existing cooperation accord.

Kuwait Oil Company's (KOC) Ahmad al-Arbeed also told the official Kuwait News Agency that talks were going on with France's Total SA for a technical assistance deal similar to those with Chevron and British Petroleum Plc.
The Total talks involve the southern al-Wafra oilfield, which has a production capacity of about 120,000 barrels per day (bpd). OPEC member Kuwait has a quota of two million bpd.
"International oil firms always aspire to secure other accords that would enable them to invest in Kuwaiti fields," Arbeed told the agency.
But no global giants have been shortlisted for such a move "because no decision has been taken yet to develop ties" beyond technical assistance accords, he added.

KUNA reported that state-owned KOC, in charge of production from the Gulf Arab state's fields, "has no intention to develop its technical assistance accord with Chevron. The issue is still under consideration and study by decision-making authorities."
Chevron's 1994 accord with KOC expires next February while BP's agreement was extended by three years in 1996.

Arbeed said KOC "is currently negotiating with Total to sign a new technical assistance accord...The aim of this is to study the latest technology in the world and pick the best to develop (Kuwait's) oilfields."
Chevron officials in Kuwait and other Western oil industry executives had expressed a wish to develop ties with KOC beyond technical assistance accords.

Industry sources say that Kuwait was considering possibly opening up the strategic, state-controlled oil sector to allow some form of direct foreign involvement in production to help meet a target of raising capacity to 3.5 million bpd by 2005 from a current 2.5 million.

Arbeed said KOC "is focusing on studying contractual formulae to allow Kuwait the best investment of its natural resources and at the same time offer the foreign investor an appropriate financial gain".
